name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: If you are a registered voter, you deserve to have your voice heard. I am deeply disappointed in today‚Äôs partisan rulings that will undoubtedly pave the path for even more voting restriction laws in states disappointed with the results of recent elections.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: In a separate ruling today, the Supreme Court decided in a California case that political donors have a "right" to anonymity. This decreases transparency in politics and allows a handful of wealthy Americans to disguise who‚Äôs really pulling the strings.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: The ruling also sided with Arizona‚Äôs ban on ballot collecting, a useful resource in rural areas ‚Äî including among Native populations ‚Äî when polling places are harder to reach and mail service isn‚Äôt always consistent.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: In Gwinnett County alone, there are over 150 voting precincts that are often subject to change between elections, causing voters to show up at the wrong location. Today‚Äôs SCOTUS ruling holds up an Arizona law declaring that votes cast in the wrong precinct can be tossed out.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text:
Minh‚Äôs dream for the future is that his daughter continues to thrive and that her children have access to a good education too. 

As for himself? ‚ÄúI look forward to retiring someday but I will stay in America. I like America.‚Äù

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: Immigrants come to our country seeking opportunity, but bring with them intelligence, creativity, innovation, and drive that makes our community stronger. It was an honor to meet Minh and share his #GA07ImmigrantStory.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: In America, their daughter had the opportunity to receive a great public education, attend pharmacy school at the University of Georgia, and get her master‚Äôs degree ‚Äî opportunities afforded to them through careful saving, a manufacturing career, and hard work.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: Five years after arriving in America, Minh took the test to become a citizen, and upon receiving his certificate, immediately started the process of sponsoring his wife to join him in America where they could start a family.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: With a background in chemistry, Minh spent time innovating and exploring how they could use recycled plastics in their products to become more environmentally responsible. He helped recruit other Vietnamese immigrants, trained them, and today is Plant Manager.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: Shortly after arriving, Minh began working a manufacturing job at AutoVentshade, now @LundInter. Two weeks were set aside for training, but Minh quickly learned the ropes in just two days. He has now worked at the company for 37 years.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: In August of 1983, Minh made the tough decision to leave behind his family, friends, and new wife to find a better life for them. Alone with only $5 in his pocket, he started his journey through Thailand and Singapore to learn American culture, and was then sent to Atlanta.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: Minh went on to earn a master‚Äôs degree in chemistry, and met his wife at the school where they both worked, but quickly realized that $10/month was not going to be enough to raise a family.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: Minh grew up in Vietnam where he excelled academically, and was chosen from a highly selective process to attend college and study chemistry. After attaining his bachelor‚Äôs degree, he became a high school teacher in South Vietnam, earning $10 per month.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: Our democracy requires people of good faith and ethics in order to make it work. Today, I ask the United States Senate to hear the evidence, to put the country before their political party, and to uphold their oath to defend our Constitution.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: Actions have consequences, and on January 6th, we saw the impact of the former president‚Äôs words, first-hand. At such a fragile moment for our country, where the very foundation of our democracy is at stake, we must have accountability.

name: Rep. Carolyn Bourdeaux
tweet_text: When I was sworn in as your congresswoman, I took an oath to support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic. The Senators who will try the former President today took the same oath. Our words matter.
